title: The Cuckoo’s Nest
author: David Crouch
text: The former docklands of Sweden’s industrial second city are now home to a cluster of high-tech companies and research institutes housed in vigorous glass and steel. So to lunch at the Cuckoo’s Nest is to rub shoulders with the entrepreneurs and academics that the bar and restaurant sets out to welcome.

Even in winter this spot is popular, so it is wise to book in advance. In summer you can sit out on the terrace overlooking the water. Swedes eat early — lunch is served from 11.30am to 2pm. You can also have breakfast there if the hotel above — the restaurant is located on the ground floor of a Radisson Blu — is not full.

To get here, clear your head and lungs with a quick hop on the ferry across the Göta river to Lindholmen — there is a frequent shuttle from Rosenlund pier, or twice an hour from the opera house. Gothenburg is a small city, so the riverside is unlikely to be more than a short walk or tram ride from your hotel.
The venue is located two minutes from the Lindholmen pier. Its comfortable, modern interior is designed to appeal to the technically minded, with mathematical equations inscribed on the bar.
The menu is limited, but enticing, and moderately priced. The bar has a selection of good wines and some excellent local beers, while its dry martinis and G & Ts are a house speciality.
